report_title: Circuit Board and Electronic Component Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: The Circuit Board and Electronic Component Manufacturing industry in the US is facing both opportunities and challenges. The CHIPS Act of 2022 provides $52 billion in funding to boost domestic semiconductor production, which could benefit circuit board manufacturers. However, the industry must navigate rising production costs and market fluctuations. Key trends include the shift towards green manufacturing and rising demand for high-power circuitry for electric vehicles. The industry's financial forecasts project modest growth from 2019-2024 but a contraction from 2024-2029.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Years of Offshoring and Competition Weigh on Revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The COVID-19 pandemic disrupted global supply chains and production capacity, leading to an imbalance between supply and demand that increased prices for electronic components and made profitability challenging.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: PCB Manufacturers Move into Electric Vehicles
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The demand for high-power load handling circuit boards for electric vehicles presented new growth opportunities for the industry, but also required more complex and sophisticated circuitry.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Green PCB Manufacturing Moves Deeper Than the Solder Mask
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The push for environmentally friendly manufacturing practices led to the development of easily disassembled and recycled circuit boards, attracting environmentally conscious consumers and buyers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Riding the Legislative Tailwinds Back to Onshore
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The CHIPS Act and regulations against China will boost demand for domestically produced components, stimulating investments in local R&D facilities and capacity expansions for US manufacturers.
As consumer electronics continue to shrink, demand for advanced circuit board designs like 3D printed, flexible, and stacked boards will increase, requiring sophisticated manufacturing processes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Design Software Moves from Manufacturers to Clients
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Major tech companies are starting to design their own circuit boards using AI-assisted tools, threatening traditional revenue models but also presenting opportunities for new services and tools.

industry_definition: Companies in the Circuit Board and Electronic component Manufacturing industry primarily manufacture electronic components, except semiconductors and related devices, such as printed circuits, circuit boards, capacitors, transformers, connectors and switches.

opportunities: Percentage of households with at least one computer
threats: Import penetration into the manufacturing sector

key_trends: COVID shocks continue supporting revenue in 2023 after creating a chip shortage that boosted circuit board sales in 2021. However, larger forces, particularly the integration of AI chips, are starting to overwhelm demand held back from COVID's shortages.
Onshoring policies drive US semiconductor performance but have only moderate effects for printed circuit board companies.
The IPC PCB provides standards for materials used in production, assembly procedures and quality control testing for printed circuit board companies.
The Supporting American Printed Circuit Boards Act of 2022 remains in its infancy but could piggyback off the support for the 2022 CHIPS Act.
Printed circuit board assembly companies require highly skilled workers and compete with advanced foreign companies.

Transportation and defense companies, respectively form a sizeable share of exports and domestic sales, particularly since national-security contractors often require domestic production for components.
California provides proximity to Asian electronic companies, Mexican automobile producers and domestic technology innovators.
The Great Lakes remains a manufacturing hub and headquarters US automobile companies despite struggles in recent decades.
Imports have a considerable share of the domestic market but face challenges from anti-trade policies.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Major purchasers of printed circuit boards and electronic components include companies in the navigational, electromedical, automotive and weapons industries.

This segment includes companies that manufacture power, distribution and specialty transformers; electric motors, generators and motor-generator sets; switchgear and switchboard apparatus; relays; and industrial controls.

Telephone apparatus manufacturers represent a significant purchaser of printed circuit boards, switches and microwave components. Cable TV equipment, global positioning system equipment, pagers, cell phones, mobile communications equipment, radio, and TV studio and broadcasting equipment rely on electronic components.

products_and_services.product_description: The printed circuit assembly segment includes computer and peripheral printed board assemblies, communications printing board assemblies, industrial process control board assemblies, instrumentation printed board assemblies for industrial processing and printed board assemblies for consumer electronics.
Other electronic components include various components that don't fall into the other categories. Other components generate 27.1% of revenue.
The electronic connectors segment includes coaxial, cylindrical, rack and panel, pin and sleeve, printed circuit and fiber optic connectors.

The bare printed circuit board segment includes printed circuit boards without mounted electronic components. Companies print, perforate, plate, screen, etch or photoprint interconnecting pathways for electric currents on laminates.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Capacitors, Resistors, Coils, Transformers and Other Inductors
products_and_services.product_description: Products in the capacitors, resistors, coils, transformers and other inductors segment include fixed and variable capacitors, thermistors, varistors, various inductors, condensers and other products.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Percentage of Households with at Least One Computer
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Printed circuit boards and electronic components go into a plethora of consumer electronics. Computer ownership typically moves in line with electronics demand. Higher computer ownership rates expand the potential market and lead to higher revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Import Penetration into the Manufacturing Sector
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Import penetration in the manufacturing sector represents the portion of domestic demand satisfied by imports. More import penetration leads to lower circuit board and electronic component manufacturing revenue.

Demand from computer manufacturers correlates directly with circuit board and electronic component manufacturer revenue. Circuit boards and components constitute a crucial input for computers and other electronic consumer products.

The trade-weighted index (TWI) represents the US dollar value relative to the currencies of major trading partners. A rising TWI signals an appreciating dollar, which makes exports more expensive for foreign customers and encourages imports. Imports threaten circuit board and electronic component manufacturers' revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Trade Shifts From China To Other Asian Competitors
international_trade_points.trade_description: China-US electronics trade has received adverse shocks from tariffs and COVID-19 in recent years. Other Asian nations have taken advantage of China-US tensions. Taiwan and South Korea remain leaders in semiconductor production and maintain strong printed circuit board supply networks. Vietnam has emerged as a fast-growing player in the printed circuit board and electronic component market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Protectionist Policies Aim To Move Production West
international_trade_points.trade_description: Former president Trump's anti-trade policies remain in place under the Biden administration. The CHIPS Act and restrictions on US semiconductor companies operating in China signal animosity toward chip and electronics trade between the US and Asia. Europe has also implemented policies to boost domestic chip protection.

business_locations.location_description: Los Angeles provides a nearby trading hub for circuit board and electronic component manufacturers to access international markets. Technology companies innovating in California rely on printed circuit board assembly to build consumer electronics. Proximity to Mexico lets exporting companies work with nearby automobile producers.
Manufacturing plants in the Great Lakes produce electronic components and bare circuit boards. Manufacturers have access to sizeable US automobile companies headquartered in the Great Lakes.

The large consumer market in the Northeast provides fertile ground for electronic component manufacturers. The New York and New Jersey port lets exporting companies access Southern US, European and African markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Institute for Printed Circuits (IPC) provides standards for circuit board assembly, including materials in production, manufacturing and design software, assembly procedures and quality control protocols.

The Electronic Components Industry Association (EICA) provides assembly standards through its EIA Technical Standards committee. Standards include general best practices and critical testing standards. Membership with the EICA gives customers peace of mind.

The EPA regulates circuit assembly and other electronic component manufacturing under the Electrical and Electronic Components (E&EC) Effluent Guidelines (1983). Printed circuit board and electronic component companies must be wary of changing regulations related to electronics' disposability.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline life cycle stage.
There is a high level of technology change in the industry.

basis_points.basis_description: Companies compete for highly skilled labor to improve efficiency and expand businesses. Onshoring prior to a significant expansion in training programs will heat up this competition.
Imports have a considerable share of the domestic market but face challenges from anti-trade policies.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Circuit boards and electronic components trade globally, reducing market share concentration. A significant volume of imports provides downstream buyers with a plethora of options.

The domestic market appears to consolidate over the years rapidly. Companies exiting the US and offshoring production give the impression of rising market share, but foreign competitors remain in the mix.

Large companies fill high-volume orders for circuit boards and electronic components. These companies dominate the domestic and international markets. The need for highly skilled labor makes printed circuit board assembly challenging to scale and expand in the US without widespread training programs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Manufacturers purchase nonferrous metals, adhesives and plastic for production. Software purchases for advanced manufacturing processes also contribute to rising costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: TRADE AND COMPLEX PRODUCTION PROCESSES MAKE ADMINISTRATIVE INVESTMENT WORTHWHILE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Companies are investing more in administrative costs to manage international trade and quality control compliance, particularly as laws against some imports from China go into effect.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: COMPANIES INVEST HEAVILY IN HUMAN CAPITAL
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Highly skilled workers play critical roles in printed circuit board assembly and electronic component manufacturing. Average wages have steadily risen alongside earnings per worker.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: THE LOW SUPPLY OF METALS AND ELECTRONIC PARTS SUPPRESSES PROFIT
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of semiconductors and metals skyrocketed alongside circuit boards and electronic components. The bump in revenue wasn't enough to send profit skyward, given substantial operating costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Paying supervisors to manage quality control weighs heavily on profit and poses a challenge to start-up companies.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The high cost of skilled labor makes scalability difficult.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments.
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Trade-War Policies Offer Relief From Import Penetration
volatility_points.volatility_description: Tariffs in 2017 on Chinese electronic imports gave US circuit board and electronic component manufacturers a higher market share. It also shuffled the competitive landscape, making Taiwan, South Korea and Vietnam greater threats.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 Disrupts Commodity And Semiconductor Supply Chains
volatility_points.volatility_description: Supply chain disruptions following COVID-19 created a shortage of commodities, production capacity and products. Metal and plastic prices spiked amid mining and shipping disruptions, raising costs for circuit board and electronic components companies. A shortage of circuit boards and components pushed the prices of end products like cars upward.

FAQs.question: How can your company leverage data analytics to identify emerging markets for circuit boards and electronic components?
FAQs.answer: Data analytics enables firms to pinpoint demand surges in sectors like IoT and automotive electronics, guiding targeted marketing strategies. By analyzing consumer behavior and market trends, companies can customize their product offerings, enhancing customer satisfaction and loyalty.

FAQs.question: What strategies can be employed to enhance the digital customer journey in the circuit board and electronic component sector?
FAQs.answer: Optimizing the digital customer journey involves integrating AR tools to visualize products in real-time, improving engagement and decision-making. Streamlining online platforms for ease of navigation and transaction can significantly reduce customer drop-off rates, boosting sales.

FAQs.question: In what ways can lean manufacturing principles be adapted to the circuit board and electronic component manufacturing processes to improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Implementing lean manufacturing tackles waste reduction and streamlines production, crucial for responding quickly to market changes in electronic components. Adopting continuous improvement practices allows for the constant evolution of operations, leading to sustained competitiveness and reduced operational costs.

FAQs.question: How can strategic partnerships within the supply chain benefit circuit board and electronic component manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Strategic partnerships, especially with raw material suppliers, ensure stable input costs and mitigate risks associated with price volatility and supply disruption. Collaboration with downstream clients can facilitate custom product development, tapping into niche markets and expanding the customer base.

FAQs.question: How can advancements in AI and machine learning be harnessed to forecast demand and optimize inventory in the circuit board industry?
FAQs.answer: AI-driven demand forecasting models offer unprecedented accuracy, allowing firms to hold optimal inventory levels, reducing holding costs, and avoiding stockouts. Machine learning algorithms analyze historical sales data to predict future buying patterns, enabling proactive adjustments to production schedules.

FAQs.question: What role does 3D printing technology play in prototyping and small-scale production for electronic components?
FAQs.answer: 3D printing accelerates the prototyping phase, allowing for rapid testing and modification of circuit board designs, thus speeding up time-to-market. For small-scale production, it offers a cost-effective alternative by eliminating the need for expensive molds and reducing material waste.

FAQs.question: With increasing global focus on environmental regulations, how can companies ensure compliance while maintaining profitability in the manufacturing of circuit boards and electronic components?
FAQs.answer: Implementing eco-friendly manufacturing practices, such as using lead-free solder and recyclable materials, meets regulatory demands and appeals to sustainability-conscious consumers. Investing in cleaner production technologies not only ensures compliance but can also reduce long-term operational costs through efficient resource use.

FAQs.question: What strategies can be implemented to navigate the complexities of international trade regulations in the circuit board and electronic component industry?
FAQs.answer: Staying abreast of changes in trade policies and leveraging legal expertise to navigate these complexities can prevent costly compliance errors and maintain smooth supply chains. Diversifying the supplier base across different geopolitical regions can mitigate risks related to tariffs and trade barriers, ensuring uninterrupted access to essential materials.

FAQs.question: How can circuit board and electronic component manufacturers optimize their capital structure to support growth while managing risk?
FAQs.answer: Employing a balanced capital structure that combines equity and debt financing optimizes the cost of capital, supporting sustainable growth without overleveraging. Regularly reviewing and adjusting the capital mix in response to market conditions and interest rate movements can protect against financial instability.

FAQs.question: In what ways can cost management strategies drive profitability in the volatile market of circuit boards and electronic components?
FAQs.answer: Implementing activity-based costing identifies high-cost activities, enabling targeted process improvements and better pricing strategies. Adopting flexible budgeting and cost monitoring in real-time allows firms to adjust quickly to fluctuations in demand, safeguarding profit.

FAQs.question: How is your company diversifying its supplier base to mitigate the risks of supply chain disruptions, especially in light of recent global events affecting the electronics sector?
FAQs.answer: Companies leveraging strong, diversified supplier links can better navigate the volatile nature of raw material availability, avoiding production hiccups that could derail operations. Fostering symbiotic relationships with suppliers not only secures a stable material flow, but also opens avenues for preferential pricing and insights into emerging materials or components, positioning companies at the forefront of innovation and cost efficiency.

FAQs.question: In what ways is your company investing in continuous education and skill upgrading of your workforce to keep pace with rapid technological advancements in the industry?
FAQs.answer: The relentless pace of innovation in the industry mandates a workforce that's not just skilled but continuously evolving. Companies that invest in ongoing training and development programs create an environment of perpetual learning, helping employees stay abreast of the latest technologies and manufacturing techniques. This commitment not only elevates the quality and efficiency of production processes but also serves as a magnet for attracting top talent who seek workplaces that promise personal growth alongside technological advancement.

FAQs.question: How is your company prioritizing investments in cutting-edge manufacturing technologies and methodologies to enhance productivity and product quality?
FAQs.answer: In an industry where precision and reliability are paramount, access to the latest technologies and manufacturing techniques is not optional—it's essential. Companies that strategically invest in state-of-the-art equipment and embrace advanced methodologies not only see a surge in productivity and efficiency but also in the quality of their output, critical factors in gaining a competitive edge.
